captions.text:
This is the new Nissan
GT-R Track Pack.
It costs 84,450 pounds.

That's 10,000 pounds more than
the standard GT-R. And it will

only be available in
the UK and Japan.

It doesn't take long to list
the modifications over the

standard GT-R because, well,
there aren't many differences.

It gets the RAYS alloys first
seen on the V-Spec car, which
save a total of 10 kilograms.

The suspension is different,
as are the dampers, but we
don't know by how much.
There are no rear seats.

The fronts have what Mizuno-san
calls magic cloth

and the rest of us just call,
well, sticky fabric.

There are front and rear cooling
ducts for the brakes,

which reduce temperatures
by up to a
claimed 100 degrees Celsius.

Now, look, I don't want to come
across like I'm being an

ungrateful sod, but when I saw
the words "Track Pack," I was

thinking, well, half cage, big
brakes, sticky tires, bucket

seats, because that's what
you need on a circuit.

But the Track Pack offers
none of those.

Is this is a marketing exercise,
or is it really the

answer to all the GT-R Track
addicts' dreams?

But there's another
side to this, too.

When Nissan launched the
GT-R in the UK, it was
under 50,000 pounds.

And now it's heading right
towards 997 Turbo territory.

Now, I know you guys from the
comments pages are getting a

bit fed up with me doing GT3
videos, so I'm going to match

it against a Turbo
S this time.

A lot more expensive, 129,000
pounds, and not specifically

designed for a circuit,
but you know what?

It's got a turbocharged
engine.

It's got a paddle
shift gearbox.
It's got four-wheel drive.

It's actually on paper a
much closer rival to
the GT-R than a GT3.

I know it's not designed to go
on a track, but it's a Porsche

Turbo so it's going to be
a bit handy, isn't it?

So the 911 Turbo S. Would
you believe it?

530 horsepower and
516 foot pounds.

Not an obvious track car and
probably not an obvious rival

to the GT-R Track Pack,
but you know what?

I've got a bit of a soft spot
for these Turbo S's.
They are quite handy.

So let's try and think about
this car driven as you would
on an evening track day.

And that's the way you're
going to use
this car, isn't it?

It's got the bucket seats,
so off we go.

I've got the gearbox in
Sport Plus, so I get
a snappy gear shift.

It's a little dulled compared
to the GT-R's, though.

I love the fact that it's so
crisp in the GT-R. You pull

the pump, and you really
like stuff's happening.

It doesn't so much
in this thing.
What have we got here?

It's still slightly slippery
here at Brands Hatch.

I've got a little bit
of front-end push.

I get on the gas, and that back
axle still wants to throw
me around a bit.
Good Lord it feels fast.

Coming down the main straight,
that's 131 miles an hour.

I don't think I've ever done
that down the main straight in
a racing car here.

Extraordinary, braking hard,
Paddock Hill, what a corner,
cambers and dips.
You know what?

This car feels really nicely
balanced because it's a
slightly damp day.

Its Bridgestone REO50s
are rather nice.

And because it's a rather damp
day, its Bridgestones are

feeling rather quite
nice and grippy.
They're clawing about.
This is a neutral car.
Look, everybody.

I've got the dampers
in normal mode.
I like this.
I really like this.
It's a nicely balanced car.

Hang the throttle, doesn't
want to rotate itself.

And it's just got so
much performance.
But do you know what?

I'm almost completely unaware
of what's going on in the
engine bay.

There's just this vague noise,
and then I'm away.

It isn't a great communicator,
but my Lord is it
impressive and fast.

Steering's not alive the way
it is in the GT3, but I'm
really impressed by this.

You could honestly do a few
track days in one of these and

not feel in any way that
you're missing out.

I think if you carried on
pounding around for too long,
things might get hot.
It's nearly 1,600 kilograms.

But it's got ceramics,
this car.

Ceramics are standard,
don't forget.

Mighty fast, watch
this performance.

Tail wants to wag now and again,
but I'm being a good

boy, I'm trying not to
drive like a yabbo.

So I'm carving the straight
line, all right?

Let that be known by people
that complain about me
drifting the whole time.

I'm going to let it cool down
a bit and have a think.

It's a mighty impressive
car, mighty impressive.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

The Track Pack does feel more
like a track car because it's
a bit sparser inside.

But it doesn't feel like
a GT-3 or anything
like that to me.
It still feels quite normal.

Again, slightly greasy
at Brands Hatch.

This is my evening track day,
British springtime.
What else do you expect?

Again, I'm going to try to
behave and not pull massive

skids everywhere because that's
immature and not the

way people behave in cars like
this, or so I'm to believe on

the comments pages
on YouTube Drive.
So here we go.
Behaving sensibly.

So I'm going to put transmission
into Race, and

I'm going to have the stability
in Race and not turn
it off completely.

This stops me doing
skids everywhere.

First of all, the car feels
bigger physically bigger.

The steering's wonderfully
sharp though.
It just changes direction.
Oh, and I'll tell you what.

Immediately, I'm getting a
feeling that the back axle
wants to move around on me.

But it's got a lot of
mechanical grip.

What you have to do is get the
car into the corner, get on

the gas, and let the clever
drifts kind of
sort it out for you.
But it is quite leery.

You can see I'm having to make
some steering corrections

where I just wasn't
in the Porsche.

Pulling ahead on the main
straight, 127 before I feel I
have to brake.

So heading into Paddock Hill,
I love this corner.

Look at it just cascade
away from me.
The car feels big.

Yellow lights on
the dashboard.
Oversteer in the middle there.

Again, through Druids, there's a
bit of a dry line appearing.

Once the rubber gets up to
temperature, these are the

same tires that you get on the
standard GT-R. But every time

I try and get on the gas, I'm
getting oversteer where I
wasn't in the Porsche.

It's a bit more of a handful
than the 911 around here.

What I have to ask myself now
is, would a standard GT-R feel
much different?

Well, this car's got some
geometry changes on it.

Apparently, on the Track Pack,
you can either have the

cambers and toes set
for Road or Track.
This one's been set for Track.

And I suspect that when
you get it really
dialed in, it is quicker.

But like anything, a faster
racing car is a more nervous
racing car, isn't it?

So there is a bit of nerviness
about this one.

The seat, well, it's got
this sort of magic
cloth stuff on it.

But I have to say it's still not
a proper bucket seat, and

I'm falling out of it a bit more
than I am in the Porsche.
And where's the harness belts?

I always thought you
should have harness
belts in a Track Pack.

Maybe this car's challenging
the conventions of what a
track car should be.

Brakes are pretty good it's
interesting these new brake

ducts in the front end, for
the rear brakes as well,
they're hidden underneath.

It's supposed to give
you 100 degrees C
less when you're braking.

I can't vouch for that, but I
can tell you that I'm not
getting too much brake fray.
This is a short circuit.
It's heavy on brakes.

It's drying out the
whole time.
Pretty mighty thing, you know.
It's a pretty mighty thing.
My problem is this.

It just reminds me how bloody
good the standard GT-R is.

It just reminds me how good
the standard GT-R is.

Typically, now I've said that
the Porsche was easier to

drive, the GT-R goes and sets
the faster lap time.
Always the case.

But these were one in traffic
and drying conditions, so

they're not worth taking
too seriously.
But there's the time anyway.

What you need to know is that
both cars are silly fast.

If this was the only GT-R, I'd
say it was astounding.

But it's hard to make sense
of the Track Pack.

It's certainly sharper
around a circuit.
That's not in any doubt.

But if you took a standard GT-R
and added 10,000 pounds

worth of modifications, that car
would be even faster, and
I suspect even better.

That's the problem with
small-volume specials.

They're often undone by the
brilliance of the car on which
they are based.

You see, I'd still have a
standard GT-R. But if I had

the money and I was looking for
a fast road car that would

handle the occasional track
session, I wouldn't have
either of these two.

The Turbo S is pant-wettingly
fast on road and track.

But I'd take a plain 997 Turbo
with folding bucket seats and

a manual gearbox, proving that
it's a funny old world.

title: Nissan GT-R Track Pack v Porsche 997 Turbo S - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.author: Hwoarang121

comments.text:
I gotta say, Chris Harris is a great Automotive journalist plain and 
simple.  he always has a very good, honest opinion of the cars and always 
admits to "pre-drive" assumptions and unfounded worries/concerns about X 
platform and then addresses the reality of those concerns when he actually 
get s to drive the cars.  Plus he manages to weave in humor without 
sounding like he's talking out his ass for the sake of being funny (good 
old English self-deprecating humor).  Great review/test aye.﻿
comments.author: Nor Wester (4Rescue)

comments.text:
+OverQuill Agreed... Although I think I could give him a run for his money 
on a Rally course.  XD

I'd just love to chat with the guy cause he always answers the questions I 
want to hear about the cars aye.  He tackles his reviews in a very analytic 
way and seems to weed out the junk that haunts some reviewers (Like Johnny 
Lieberger or Mike Spinelli, both of whom suck behind the wheel and in front 
of the camera).  I'm gonna have to go out to the local rally tracks next 
time I'm in the UK and see if I can run into the guy.
comments.author: Nor Wester (4Rescue)

comments.text:
I gotta agree. I feel he's fair and there's a genuineness to what he

advice when it comes to buying a car... even if said cars are far out of my 
price range.

comments.author: Andy Mac

comments.text:
Excellent review, and I knew that the cost of the Nissan's would start to 
rise over the years, that was a no brainier.   And for Nissan to even 
really approach the work and time it takes to really make a car of bespoke 
quality, craftsmanship and ultimately something that you can truly call 
your own then the price would have to rise.  For the Japanese to beat the 
rest of the world.   This is just another time in Japanese Car 
Manufacturing to choose between just offering packages that have one 
itty-bitty thing that everyone wants but that same package no one else 
cares for - or for them to finally offer - a la some of the Europeans best 
automakers.   Especially now that they are charging as much as they are for 
something they gave a name too that it surely doesn't do in the first place﻿

comments.text:
American: BIG, not the best in quality but at least pretty good value for 
money Japanese: Efficient, reliable, and always trying to be the best in 
terms of technical, lacks of soul and fun though. German: Solid made, high 
quality interior, precisioon engineering, but could be pricy. British: 
Charismatic, traditional ( Doesnt mean conservative), random in terms of 
quality and technical. French: Unique, most (Not all) are likely to be soft 
cars. Italian: Emotional, but not the most advanced
comments.author: YouTubeYouTube

comments.text:
I think Italian is quirky too lol But they pure more soul to the car than 
the British
comments.author: YouTubeYouTube

comments.text:
I drove em both! (ofcourse I didn't, but everybody on youtube has) I think 
they are both by far not as good as the brand new Dacia Duster. (will be 
available from the 1st of November) It actually has 3 petrol options and 
Diesel. The GTR only has 1 engine option (with or without any) and the same 
goes for the 911. Besides the duster has a grippy 4wd system as well..

comments.text:
you just cant argue about taste. i love the nsx the supra the s2k the old 
datsun 510 and the 240z of course the kpgc10 and a lot more. my taste is 
almost all the time about coupes. i like them clean and simple. like the 
silvias the jdm integra. dont forget the rx7. for its year it has a 
remarkable design. and i like also the 80s look of the japanese cars. like 
the 1st mr2 the celica 2800 the starion and the accord. but i have to say 
there are not many newer japanese or other cars i like.
comments.author: 99Lezard99

comments.text:
I disagree that Japanese make "nice designed" cars when it comes to 
esthetics. I've owned quite a number of Japanese vehicles (Honda, Yamaha, 
Kawasaki, Toyota, NIssan). However, their looks never inspire. Overall, 
Japanese build reliable and functional vehicles with esthetics as an 
afterthought. As for USA, they make nice looking vehicles but they just 
miss the details (for example, my Cadillac doesn't have perfect seams 
anywhere on the car).
comments.author: TheOccTher

comments.text:
I stand corrected. I wish I could update my posting. But you must admit 
that Brits do make quirky cars. I loved my Triumph Spitfire and 955i 
motorcycle. The electrics on British vehicles are enough to make you insane.
comments.author: TheOccTher

comments.text:
usa: big engine, little hp, no cornering, no quality. big and bigger 
torque, biggest cars, nice but offensiv design. german: not really 
technical reliable, a lot are dead boring, they think they are the best. 
expensive. very good interior quality. japanese: reliable, good technical 
quality, pretty big bang for the buck (here in germany at least) a lot of 
nice designed cars. expensive spareparts, just an ok interior design and 
quality french: dont care, wierd design. italy: nice design, crap tech
